text: Where the `???` there is something like `Dict("x-amz-acl" => "public-read", ...)` and it's unclear what else is required there. I was hoping for something a bit more hand-hold-y.

text:
These deeper parts are a bit of the dark side still as AWS.jl doesn’t look at Request object parameter shapes.

You’ll need to create the XML Object yourself,

<https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/acl-overview.html>

attachments.title: Access control list (ACL) overview - Amazon Simple Storage Service
attachments.text: Amazon S3 access control lists (ACLs) enable you to manage access to buckets and objects. Each bucket and object has an ACL attached to it as a subresource. It defines which AWS accounts or groups are granted access and the type of access. When a request is received against a resource, Amazon S3 checks the corresponding ACL to verify that the requester has the necessary access permissions.
attachments.fallback: Access control list (ACL) overview - Amazon Simple Storage Service

text:
To make this easier for end users you need to look at the service shapes:

- <https://github.com/aws/aws-sdk-js/blob/master/apis/s3-2006-03-01.normal.json#L1479>

And traverse down each sub-object. It’s a bit less trivial and something which I’d like to do, but it’ll take time to think of a good way to represent this to the end user. So for now you’ll have to make some String and convert it to XML :grimacing:

AWSS3 has a few examples of this sort of stuff,

- <https://github.com/JuliaCloud/AWSS3.jl/blob/2b564443281d72c5520cbc3a156e479c35d9ee2a/src/AWSS3.jl#L272-L274>

attachments.title: PutObjectAcl - Amazon Simple Storage Service
attachments.text: Uses the acl subresource to set the access control list (ACL) permissions for a new or existing object in an S3 bucket. You must have WRITE_ACP permission to set the ACL of an object. For more information, see What permissions can I grant? in the
